questions.query: Telegram Handle We Can Use To Contact You
Link to your Public Group Chat
Have you participated in a previous Gitcoin Grants Round? If so, please name the rounds or link the builder profile to prior rounds.
How does your project contribute significantly to the Ethereum network's infrastructure? Please provide specific examples and metrics if available.
questions.explanation:
Samba significantly strengthens the Ethereum network's infrastructure by expanding the diversity and decentralization of Portal Clients. As a Java-based implementation, Samba adds a new technology stack to the Portal Network, enabling broader participation—especially from environments like Android and Ethereum clients like Besu. This enhances network resilience and accessibility by distributing historical data storage across more diverse nodes. 
Samba contributes directly to reducing the storage burden on Ethereum nodes, supporting the vision of lightweight, history-free nodes that can still access historical data on demand. 
This helps make Ethereum more scalable and accessible, especially in resource-constrained environments. 
From a technical standpoint, Samba is well on its way to becoming fully Portal-compliant. To date, we have: Implemented 15 of the 26 suggested Portal endpoints. Passed 357 out of 360 tests on Portal Hive, demonstrating strong interoperability and correctness. 
These milestones mark significant progress toward a stable, production-ready release that will offer a valuable addition to Ethereum's decentralized storage layer.

questions.query: Describe any pioneering development work in your project, particularly in enhancing privacy, interoperability, or user experience.
questions.explanation:
Samba introduces a Java-based implementation of a fully Portal-compliant client, expanding the diversity and interoperability of the Portal Network. Its integration will offer immediate benefits in terms of interoperability, as it can be used as a standalone client, embedded as a library, or integrated as a plugin in clients like Besu—broadening the accessibility of the Portal Network across different platforms, including mobile environments like Android.
While the full set of use cases for the Portal Network is still emerging, Samba will improve the user and developer experience. It simplifies access to Ethereum’s historical data by offering lightweight, efficient alternatives to traditional archive nodes. Developers will be able to query historical data either through the execution layer or directly via Samba's JSON-RPC endpoints. This reduces complexity, saves storage, and opens up new possibilities for dApp developers to sync and consume historical data in more flexible and efficient ways.
In this way, Samba will not only help build the foundation of a decentralized storage layer but also will shape the future UX of interacting with Ethereum history.

questions.query: What specific problems or challenges in the Ethereum ecosystem does your project address? How does your solution improve upon existing alternatives?
questions.explanation:
Samba addresses a key scalability challenge in the Ethereum ecosystem: the growing storage burden on full nodes. By aligning with EIP-4444 and the Portal Network vision, Samba enables nodes to discard older historical data while still allowing efficient access to it through the decentralized Portal protocol.
This significantly reduces the storage requirements for participating nodes, lowering the cost and technical barrier to running a node. As a result, it improves overall network scalability, promotes greater decentralization, and makes Ethereum more accessible—especially for users operating in resource-constrained environments.
Compared to traditional archive nodes or existing solutions that require maintaining the full history locally, Samba offers a lightweight, modular alternative that preserves access to historical data without compromising node efficiency.

questions.query: Outline your project's roadmap and how the grant funds will be used to achieve your development goals.
questions.explanation:
This grant will directly support the continued development of Samba as we work toward full compliance with the Portal Network specifications. Specifically, it will enable our team to continue the implementation of all defined sub-networks and ensure Samba is production-ready.
Roadmap:
Complete the History Subnetwork: Finalize support for the history subnetwork
Develop the Besu Plugin: Build and integrate a Samba plugin for Besu, allowing Portal functionality to be easily adopted by an existing Java-based Ethereum client.
Implement the Execution-State Subnetwork.
Implement the Beacon Chain Subnetwork.
The grant will fund:
Ongoing protocol development and testing
Integration work (especially with Besu)
Subnetworks implementations
Stability, performance, and security improvements
Developer resources and documentation to support adoption

questions.query: How does your project contribute to the decentralization and security of the Ethereum network?
questions.explanation:
Our project contributes to the decentralization and security of the Ethereum network in several key ways:

Client Diversity & Technical Decentralization: By introducing Samba, the first Portal Client written in Java, we expand the diversity of Portal client implementations. This aligns with Ethereum’s multi-client philosophy and reduces reliance on any single language or codebase, making the network more resilient to bugs, attacks, or implementation failures.


Network Integrity & Robustness: Samba strengthens the overall integrity of the Portal Network by adding redundancy and failover capability. A more diverse and distributed set of clients helps ensure that the network remains operational and secure, even in the face of localized disruptions or targeted attacks.


Security Through Shared Infrastructure: We leverage and test key components from established Ethereum clients like Besu (execution layer) and Teku (consensus layer), contributing to a safer and more unified ecosystem across layers.


Lowering Barriers to Participation: Samba can be run as a standalone node or integrated directly into Besu, making it easier for more individuals and developers to participate in the network. This lowers the technical and storage barriers to running a node, leading to increased node count and improved decentralization and security.


All of these efforts support the broader goals of the Portal Networks:  to provide reliable, lightweight, and decentralized access to the Ethereum protocol.

questions.query: For any project deploying smart contracts on blockchain networks, please list all your deployer addresses and their corresponding blockchain networks. Use this format for each entry: [deployer_address], [chain_id]—for example, 0x123abc..., 42161 (This represents a deployer address on the Arbitrum network). Please include a separate line for each unique deployer address and blockchain combination.
